title: Conductors - solid conducting sphere in ext field

content.question: Two parallel plates are charged with equal amounts of charge but opposite sign and separated by a distance <math alttext="the fraction d over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. A neutral, solid conducting sphere of radius <math alttext="R less than the fraction, d over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>R</mi><mo><</mo><mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>d</mi></mstyle><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math> is placed between the oppositely charged plates. In Case <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> there is a charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mstyle></math> on the positive plate. In Case <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> there is a charge <math alttext="positive 2 Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>Q</mi></mstyle></math> on the positive plate. Which of the following correctly compares the electric field <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> inside the sphere in Case <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> to the electric field <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math> inside the sphere in Case <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub 2 equals one half E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="E sub 2 equals E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub 2 equals 2 E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

The electric field cannot be determined without knowing the radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> of the sphere relative to the plate separation distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub 2 equals E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>
